subject: Re: [junit] Class coupling measure?
msgSnippet: ... By the way, you can also point the  at a directory of class files. JDepend examines file extensions (either .java or .class) to employ the
messageBody:
Chuck Stern wrote:

> Here is my ant target for jdepend:
>
> <target name="dependencies" depends="init" >
> <property name="depends.dir" value="${docs.dir}/metrics" />
> <mkdir dir="${depends.dir}" />
>
> <!-- NOTE: you need the jdepend.jar in your classpath -->
> <jdepend outputfile="${depends.dir}/jdepend.xml" fork="yes"
> format="xml">
> <sourcespath>
> <pathelement location="${src.java.dir}" />
> </sourcespath>
> </jdepend>
>
> <style basedir="${depends.dir}" destdir="${depends.dir}"
> includes="jdepend.xml"
> style="${optional.files.dir}/jdepend/jdepend.xsl"/>
>
> </target>

By the way, you can also point the <sourcespath> at a directory of class files.
JDepend examines file extensions (either .java or .class) to employ the
appropriate parser. Class file parsing is generally more accurate in its
ability to identify referenced packages not directly visible from 'package' or
'import' statements. If a given directory contains both a source file and a
class file for the same Java class, then the class file is analyzed and the
source file is ignored. Class files must exist in a directory; JAR files are
currently not supported.

Enjoy!

Mike
